bibl.title: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Laura Armistead Carter, September 15, 1925

div1.p: Rosenau sends his condolences upon the death of Henry Carter.

div1.head: Letter from M.J. Rosenau to Laura Armistead Carter, September 15, 1925

opener.dateline:
HARVARD UNIVERSITY
MEDICAL SCHOOL
DEPARTMENT OF PREVENTIVE MEDICINE AND HYGIENE
Boston, Massachusetts
September 15, 1925.

div1.p:
I appreciate more than I can tell you the time and
pains you take to write me concerning your father. Your letter,
however, brought mixed feelings, for I am greatly distressed to
discover that he is suffering and has lost ground.

I look back with much satisfaction on our trip last
summer, when he received in part personal recognition for the
distinguished services and contributions he has made to mankind,
but one of the joys of life is to feel that I have had a place
in the friendships of your father's great heart. As you know,
I have always had the highest admiration for his nobility of
character, as well as his extraordinary habit of mind. I know
no one whose mental processes were so alert, so keen, so crit-
ical, and whose judgments were so sure and logic so convincing.
His personality surrounded him as an aura which had a particular
appeal to me, and I recall almost verbatim certain conversations
which were both stimulating and inspiring.

I did not start this letter with the intention of
writing a eulogy, but these thoughts just naturally come out,
and I am always glad to give them voice. I was in Washington
2
Sunday and saw Mrs. Goldberger and Mrs. McCoy, and learned
from them that things were not going well. I would have
stopped in, but was advised not to do so in view of all the
circumstances. If, however, I can be of any service at any
time, command me and you know I will gladly serve.
My wife joins me in everything.
div1.closer:
Very sincerely yours, M. J. Rosenau Miss Laura Armistead Carter,
2212 Columbia Street, N. W.,
Washington, D. C.
I wrote this letter this morning - now comes your
telegram which tells of the end. Death is a shock
even though it is a release - I feel that I
have suffered a personal loss, but what must
your feelings be. My words cannot assurge your
grief - How you will miss these noble soul.
I wish I could be of some use. Tell me.
With best of love
M. M.
